title: Circularity as Tradition: Session 4 Highlights
content:
üèîÔ∏è Session 4 from Nordic Circular Summit in Nuuk, Greenland

"In Greenland, circularity isn't a trend, it's a tradition and it's the foundation."
‚Äî Frederik Thrane, Lifestyle and Design Cluster, Denmark

Key Takeaways from Arctic & Nordic Lifestyles:

üß£ GREVILLIOT - QUOTA AS SUSTAINABILITY DRIVER
Mia Chemnitz: "We are always limited by quotas. We are sold out all the time."

‚Ä¢ Complete traceability: "I can tell you who made every product"
‚Ä¢ From wild musk ox ‚Üí hunter ‚Üí hide ‚Üí yarn ‚Üí garment (all local)
‚Ä¢ Only 1 external step: spinning (no facilities in Greenland)
‚Ä¢ Repair built-in: "The maker is probably the best in the world to repair it"

üêü ROYAL GREENLAND - REINTRODUCING THE FORGOTTEN
Kristian Ottesen: "We don't have to reinvent the wheel. We have to listen and learn from the history."

‚Ä¢ 38 outposts throughout Greenland
‚Ä¢ Sole employer in smallest settlements
‚Ä¢ Industrialization = forgetting circular practices
‚Ä¢ Now: reintroducing pre-industrial wisdom

üì± DIGITAL PRODUCT PASSPORT
Gisle Mariani Mardal (NFTA, Norway): "Not having control is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."

Tilda Larsson (Ludwig Svensson, 137-year-old Swedish manufacturer): "I can receive information very easy and very quick because we have production in-house."

üåç THE CULTURAL SHIFT
Lise Lotte: "Nothing or less waste is possible when knowledge + materials + community are interconnected."

Nordic societies = individualistic
Greenlandic society = collectivistic

"We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen while we share."

#CircularEconomy #ArcticWisdom #InuitTraditions #DigitalProductPassport #SustainableFashion #Greenland #NordicCircularSummit
media_suggestion: Carousel with 5 slides: session title, Grevilliot story, Royal Greenland story, DPP explanation, cultural wisdom

title: The Scarf That's More Than a Scarf
content:
üí¨ "Your scarf is not just a scarf.

It's a bit of a history, a culture, and tradition.

And a meal."

‚Äî Lise Lotte, Co-moderator from Qaanaaq, North Greenland

This perfectly captures what we learned at #NordicCircularSummit Session 4.

Grevilliot's musk ox wool scarves:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Wild animal hunted for MEAT (primary purpose)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Hide purchased from local hunter
3Ô∏è‚É£ Wool taken from hide
4Ô∏è‚É£ Shipped for spinning (only external step)
5Ô∏è‚É£ Returned as yarn to Greenland
6Ô∏è‚É£ Knitted by known local artisans
7Ô∏è‚É£ Sold with complete story

"I can tell you who made every product in our store." ‚Äî Mia Chemnitz, Grevilliot

This is what complete traceability looks like.
This is what community-embedded production looks like.
This is what "waste as foundation" looks like.

We hunt for the meat. And then we wear the rest.

In Greenland, circularity isn't a trend‚Äîit's how you survive the Arctic for millennia.

What if we stopped trying to invent circular economy and started listening to those who never abandoned it?

#CircularEconomy #TraditionalKnowledge #Traceability #SustainableFashion #Greenland #InuitWisdom
speaker: Lise Lotte & Mia Chemnitz
media_suggestion: Quote card with scarf image and Lise Lotte's quote

title: Traditional Knowledge vs. Academic Proof
content:
‚ùì How do you measure the performance of seal skin?

Water pressure resistance? ‚ùå
Breathability ratings? ‚ùå
Insulation values? ‚ùå
Laboratory tests? ‚ùå

"I don't know that there has been any tests."
‚Äî Mia Chemnitz, Grevilliot, Greenland

But when asked what she'd wear on the ice cap or dog sled:

‚úÖ "I trust the seal skin more than anything that's been tested a lot. I know what I'm going to be wearing."

This is the epistemological challenge of circular economy.

Western industrial model demands:
üìä Quantifiable metrics
üî¨ Laboratory testing
üìÑ Peer-reviewed research
üèÜ Standardized certifications

Traditional knowledge offers:
‚è≥ Millennia of lived experience
üèîÔ∏è Survival as proof of efficacy
üë• Cultural transmission of expertise
üåç Place-based adaptation

The question isn't whether seal skin performs well.

Inuit survival across thousands of years proves it does.

The question is: **Can we value knowledge systems that don't produce the documentation our systems demand?**

"Even the knowledge that might not be academically proven yet, but that has a couple of millennia to prove the value of the outcomes." ‚Äî Frederik Thrane

Circular economy won't succeed by only valuing what we can measure in labs.

It will succeed when we expand what counts as valid evidence.

#TraditionalKnowledge #CircularEconomy #InuitWisdom #Sustainability #EpistemicJustice #Arctic #Innovation
speaker: Mia Chemnitz & Frederik Thrane
media_suggestion: Split image: laboratory vs. Arctic environment

title: Circularity as Tradition
content:
"In Greenland, circularity isn't a trend, it's a tradition and it's the foundation."

‚Äî Frederik Thrane at #NordicCircularSummit

Maybe we don't need to invent circular economy.
Maybe we need to listen to those who never abandoned it.

#ArcticWisdom #CircularEconomy
speaker: Frederik Thrane

title: Quota Limitations
content:
Grevilliot's business model:

‚ùå Can't scale beyond quotas
‚ùå No discount for volume
‚ùå Sold out all the time

‚úÖ 100% local production
‚úÖ Complete traceability
‚úÖ Community pride
‚úÖ Sustainable by design

Scarcity isn't a bug. It's a feature.

#CircularFashion
speaker: Mia Chemnitz

title: The Maker is the Repairer
content:
"The person who made the garment is probably the best in the world to repair it. You just come back and they fix it."

‚Äî Mia Chemnitz, Grevilliot

What ESPR tries to mandate, local relationships make natural.

#RightToRepair #CircularEconomy
speaker: Mia Chemnitz

title: Cultural Decolonization Through Materials
content:
‚úä TAKING IT BACK ‚úä

"15 years ago, we were all wearing Canada Goose jackets. But part of what we're trying to do is take these amazing materials that we have here and make them fashionable again."

‚Äî Mia Chemnitz, Grevilliot, Greenland üá¨üá±

THE DECOLONIZATION MOVEMENT:

ü™° Taking back our TATTOOS
üíé Taking back our EARRINGS
üß• Taking back our ANORAK
ü¶å Taking back our MATERIALS
üéµ Taking back our CULTURE
üé∂ Taking back our MUSIC

...EVERYTHING.

For decades:
‚ùå Traditional materials = "primitive"
‚ùå Industrial materials = "progress"
‚ùå Cultural erasure
‚ùå Dependency on imports

NOW:
‚úÖ Traditional materials = more durable
‚úÖ Traditional materials = more repairable
‚úÖ Traditional materials = more sustainable
‚úÖ Traditional materials = locally sourced
‚úÖ Traditional materials = culturally meaningful

Indigenous communities are reclaiming what was dismissed.

Not as a return to the past‚Äîas a path to a sustainable future.

Products Greenlandic people are "very proud of."

Circular economy is discovering what Indigenous peoples never forgot.

Learned at #NordicCircularSummit in Nuuk, Greenland.

#CulturalDecolonization #IndigenousKnowledge #InuitWisdom #SustainableFashion #TraditionalKnowledge #Greenland #CircularEconomy #Nuuk #ArcticWisdom #LocalMaterials #Grevilliot
speaker: Mia Chemnitz
media_suggestion: Carousel showing traditional Greenlandic materials and garments

title: Digital Product Passport Explained
content:
üì± DIGITAL PRODUCT PASSPORT üì±
What is it and why should you care?

üîç WHAT:
"A way of connecting a physical product to the digital grid. The easiest way to explain it is a QR code connected to the product."
‚Äî Gisle Mariani Mardal, NFTA, Norway

Think: Restaurant menu during pandemic, but for your clothes.

üìã WHAT IT CONTAINS:
‚Ä¢ Production information
‚Ä¢ Working conditions
‚Ä¢ How to repair it
‚Ä¢ Resale connections
‚Ä¢ Material composition
‚Ä¢ End-of-life handling

‚è∞ WHEN:
Mandatory for EU market access by 2030

üí∞ WHY IT MATTERS:
"Not having control is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."
‚Äî Gisle Mariani Mardal

Plus: Extended Producer Responsibility fees easier to manage when you can track products.

üè≠ WHO HAS ADVANTAGE:
Local manufacturers like Ludwig Svensson (Sweden, founded 1887):

"When I discussed with other companies about their supply chains, they told me how many steps they need to go back to get information. I can contact all the departments here and receive information very easy and very quick."
‚Äî Tilda Larsson, Product Development Engineer

‚úÖ THE BOTTOM LINE:
‚Ä¢ Compliance = market access
‚Ä¢ Transparent supply chains = easier compliance
‚Ä¢ Opaque supply chains = expensive, difficult
‚Ä¢ Local production = competitive advantage
‚Ä¢ Control = cost savings

üå± THE VISION:
"It should not be hard to be sustainable. It should be easy to do right."
‚Äî Tilda Larsson

Learn more at #NordicCircularSummit

#DigitalProductPassport #DPP #ESPR #SustainableFashion #Transparency #CircularEconomy #LocalProduction #SupplyChain #Traceability #EU #Sustainability #TextileInnovation
speaker: Gisle Mariani Mardal & Tilda Larsson
media_suggestion: Infographic showing DPP concept with QR code visual

title: Arctic & Nordic Lifestyles - Session 4 Recap
content:
üèîÔ∏è ARCTIC & NORDIC LIFESTYLES - Session 4 Recap from Nuuk, Greenland! üá¨üá±

What happens when you bring together Greenlandic entrepreneurs, a 300-year-old seafood company, Norwegian textile experts, and Swedish manufacturers to discuss circular economy?

You discover that circularity isn't something to invent‚Äîit's something to remember. üí°

TOP MOMENTS:

üß£ MIA CHEMNITZ (Grevilliot, Greenland)
"We hunt for the meat. And then we wear the rest."

Mia's company makes garments from musk ox wool and sealskin. Complete local production. Every product traceable to the hunter. Limited by sustainable quotas (sold out all the time). The maker is the best repairer. No academic tests for sealskin performance, but millennia of Inuit survival prove it works.

Cultural decolonization in action: "We are taking back our materials, culture, music‚Äîeverything."

üêü KRISTIAN OTTESEN (Royal Greenland)
"We don't have to reinvent the wheel. We have to listen and learn from the history."

A Dane who moved to Greenland to reintroduce circular practices that were abandoned during industrialization. 38 outposts throughout Greenland, sole employer in smallest settlements. "Waste not, have not, want not" is culturally embedded.

üì± GISLE MARIANI MARDAL (NFTA, Norway)
"Not having control over your supply chain is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."

Explained Digital Product Passports (DPP): QR codes connecting products to complete supply chain data. Mandatory for EU market by 2030. Transparent supply chains = easier compliance. Makes sustainability easy, not hard.

üá∏üá™ TILDA LARSSON (Ludwig Svensson, Sweden, founded 1887)
"I can receive information very easy and very quick because we have production in-house."

137-year-old textile manufacturer with full production line in Sweden. Shows how local manufacturing makes DPP implementation simple compared to complex global supply chains.

üåç LISE LOTTE (Independent Consultant, from Qaanaaq, North Greenland)
"Nothing or less waste is possible when knowledge + materials + community are interconnected."

"We have two ears and one mouth, so we should listen while we share."

Born in Greenland's northernmost village, Lise Lotte highlighted the cultural divide: Nordic societies are individualistic, Greenlandic society is collectivistic. Circular economy requires collectivist values‚Äîsharing, collaboration, community benefit.

KEY LESSONS:

‚úÖ Circularity in Greenland = tradition, not trend
‚úÖ Quota limitations = sustainability by design
‚úÖ Complete traceability builds trust and value
‚úÖ The maker = the best repairer
‚úÖ Traditional knowledge ‚â• academic proof
‚úÖ Cultural decolonization = circular economy
‚úÖ DPP = competitive advantage for transparent companies
‚úÖ Local production = easier DPP compliance
‚úÖ Collectivism > individualism for circularity
‚úÖ Listen while you share (two ears, one mouth)

THE BIG PICTURE:

"Your scarf is not just a scarf. It's a bit of a history, a culture, and tradition. And a meal." ‚Äî Lise Lotte

When products embody history, culture, tradition, and sustenance, they can't be thrown away. They have too much meaning.

Circular economy isn't about inventing new systems. It's about learning from those who never abandoned circular principles.

Thank you to everyone in Nuuk and online! üôè

Full transcript, article, and key quotes available at nordiccircularsummit.com/transcripts

#CircularEconomy #ArcticWisdom #InuitTraditions #Greenland #NordicCircularSummit #Nuuk #SustainableFashion #DigitalProductPassport #TraditionalKnowledge #CulturalDecolonization #LocalProduction
media_suggestion: Photo album from session with all speakers

title: Collectivism vs. Individualism in Circular Economy
content:
üîÑ Why does circular economy struggle in the Nordics?

Here's a cultural insight from Lise Lotte at #NordicCircularSummit:

**"Nordic societies are individualistic.
Greenlandic society is collectivistic."**

This matters profoundly because circular economy fundamentally requires:

ü§ù Sharing resources
‚ôªÔ∏è Collaborative consumption
üë• Collective ownership models
üìö Knowledge sharing
üåç Community benefit over individual profit

All of these are **collectivist values**.

Individualistic societies struggle with them.

As Frederik Thrane noted:
"We, from a Nordic perspective, need to practice even more to be collectivistic, to share more, especially when it comes to knowledge, especially when it comes to enabling, connecting the dots that need to be connected."

Lise Lotte's closing wisdom:

**"We do have two ears and one mouth, so I really would like that we listen. While we share, we listen as well."**

The transition to circular economy is not primarily technical or economic.

It's cultural.

The Nordics have expertise to share:
‚Ä¢ Technology ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Finance ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Policy frameworks ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Market access ‚úÖ

Arctic and Indigenous communities have wisdom to share:
‚Ä¢ Traditional knowledge ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Place-based practices ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Collectivist values ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ Circular thinking that was never broken ‚úÖ

The transition will only succeed if both sides **listen at least twice as much as they speak**.

What cultural shifts does your organization need to embrace circular thinking?

#CircularEconomy #OrganizationalCulture #IndigenousWisdom #Collectivism #SystemsChange #Sustainability #Leadership
speaker: Lise Lotte & Frederik Thrane

title: Waste as Foundation: Inverting the Business Model
content:
üí° Most companies create waste as a byproduct.

Grevilliot built their business ON waste.

Here's the inversion:

üî¥ CONVENTIONAL MODEL:
1. Design product
2. Source virgin materials
3. Manufacture
4. Sell
5. Create waste
6. Try to minimize waste (afterthought)

üü¢ GREVILLIOT MODEL:
1. Hunters harvest seals for MEAT (primary purpose)
2. Sealskin becomes available ("waste product")
3. Grevilliot purchases hides from local hunters
4. Transforms into premium garments
5. Complete local production
6. Zero waste from start

Mia Chemnitz explains:

**"We are basically a company founded on waste product, because we hunt for the meat. And then we wear the rest."**

**"Of course, we've never thought of seal skin as a waste product in Greenland. It's very evident, if you look back, that Inuit have survived in the Arctic because of the seal and also because of the seal skin."**

Her challenge to global businesses:

**"I kind of want to challenge companies to start with, okay, we have this waste, let's look at it, and what can we do with it?"**

Don't minimize waste as an afterthought.
**Build your business on the waste.**

This is the fundamental reframe circular economy requires.

What the linear economy calls "waste" is the foundation.

Examples across sectors:
‚Ä¢ Seafood: Royal Greenland transforming side streams into value (Session 2)
‚Ä¢ Fashion: Grevilliot using sealskin from meat harvesting
‚Ä¢ Agriculture: Breweries using spent grain for food products
‚Ä¢ Construction: Excess materials becoming new buildings

The question for your business:

What "waste" are you sitting on that could be your next revenue stream?

Learned at #NordicCircularSummit Session 4: Arctic & Nordic Lifestyles

#CircularEconomy #BusinessModel #Innovation #Sustainability #WasteToValue #ZeroWaste #Greenland #InuitWisdom
speaker: Mia Chemnitz
media_suggestion: Diagram showing conventional vs. Grevilliot model

title: Two Ears, One Mouth
content:
"We do have two ears and one mouth, so I really would like that we listen. While we share, we listen as well."

‚Äî Lise Lotte, Qaanaaq, North Greenland

Circular economy's most important skill:

Listening. üëÇüëÇ

#ArcticWisdom #CircularEconomy
speaker: Lise Lotte

title: The Journey of a Scarf
content:
üß£ THE JOURNEY OF A SCARF üß£

From Frederik Thrane's question:
"Where did my scarf start?"

To Mia Chemnitz's answer:

üìç STEP 1: MOUNTAIN
Wild musk ox on mountains near Kangerlussuaq, Greenland

üìç STEP 2: HUNTER
Local hunter harvests animal for meat (primary purpose)
Sells hide to Grevilliot

üìç STEP 3: PROCESSING
Wool removed from hide
Only in coldest part of winter (2-month window)
Limited by sustainable quotas

üìç STEP 4: SPINNING (only external step)
Shipped out for spinning (no facility in Greenland)
Returned as yarn

üìç STEP 5: KNITTING
Knitted by local artisans
Mia knows who made it

üìç STEP 6: SALE
Sold with complete story
Often for special occasions
No impulse buys from locals

üìç STEP 7: REPAIR (when needed)
"The person who made the garment is probably the best in the world to repair it. You just come back and they fix it."

üìç STEP 8: MEANING
"Your scarf is not just a scarf. It's a bit of a history, a culture, and tradition. And a meal." ‚Äî Lise Lotte

THIS IS WHAT COMPLETE TRACEABILITY LOOKS LIKE.

‚úÖ Every material from local hunter
‚úÖ Every maker known personally
‚úÖ Every step understood
‚úÖ Every product tells a story
‚úÖ Every purchase supports community

Compare to conventional fashion:
‚ùå Unknown makers
‚ùå Multi-country supply chains
‚ùå Opaque processes
‚ùå No repair options
‚ùå Anonymous transactions

Grevilliot shows what's possible when:
Knowledge + Materials + Community = Interconnected

Learn more at #NordicCircularSummit

#Grevilliot #Greenland #SustainableFashion #Traceability #CircularEconomy #LocalProduction #MuskOx #InuitTraditions #ArcticWisdom #ZeroWaste #SlowFashion #Nuuk
speaker: Mia Chemnitz & Lise Lotte
media_suggestion: Carousel showing each step with photos

title: Royal Greenland: Reintroducing What Was Never Forgotten
content:
üêü ROYAL GREENLAND: 300 Years of Evolution

Kristian Ottesen's journey is a powerful case study in circular transformation:

üìç BACKGROUND:
‚Ä¢ Danish national working in Greenland
‚Ä¢ Previously: textiles in China (trying to make industry sustainable)
‚Ä¢ Then: seaweed cultivation
‚Ä¢ Now: waste stream valorization at Royal Greenland

THE PARADOX:

**"This has been done for centuries before we or I came along, but now we are reintroducing it."**

What happened?

üè≠ INDUSTRIALIZATION PHASE:
‚Ä¢ Efficiency prioritized over tradition
‚Ä¢ Circular practices abandoned
‚Ä¢ Waste streams created
‚Ä¢ Knowledge forgotten

üîÑ REINTRODUCTION PHASE (NOW):
‚Ä¢ Recognizing cultural wisdom
‚Ä¢ **"Waste not, have not, want not"** culturally embedded
‚Ä¢ Easy to reintroduce because culture remembers
‚Ä¢ Side streams becoming revenue streams

üåç THE INFRASTRUCTURE:
‚Ä¢ **38 outposts** throughout Greenland
‚Ä¢ **Sole employer** in smallest settlements
‚Ä¢ Sometimes "just three people and a freezer"
‚Ä¢ Connecting tiny communities to global markets

**"Even the smallest settlements in Greenland have actually a global market reach in a way. So it's kind of beautiful."**

THE LEARNING:

**"We don't have to reinvent the wheel. We have to listen and learn from the history and then just reinstate some of the practices."**

This is the pattern:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Traditional societies practiced circularity (necessity)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Industrialization = abandoning circular practices
3Ô∏è‚É£ Current moment = "innovation" = reintroducing what was lost

The "innovations" we celebrate‚Äîwaste valorization, resource efficiency, local production‚Äîare often just re-learning what traditional societies never forgot.

Kristian's role as an outsider who learns, respects, and helps reintroduce is a model for circular transformation everywhere.

Humility + Cultural respect + Systems thinking = Real change

What traditional practices has your industry forgotten that need reintroducing?

#CircularEconomy #RoyalGreenland #Greenland #TraditionalKnowledge #OrganizationalTransformation #Seafood #WasteToValue #CulturalWisdom #NordicCircularSummit
speaker: Kristian Ottesen

title: Nordic-Baltic Collaboration
content:
"Not one country can figure out the textile circular system."

‚Äî Kalli Kent, Nordic Baltic Textile Transition Group

Nordics consume textiles.
Baltics receive the used textiles.

Solution? Collaborate.

Regional thinking > national thinking.

#CircularTextiles
speaker: Kalli Kent

title: DPP Implementation: Local Manufacturing Advantage
content:
üì± DIGITAL PRODUCT PASSPORT: The Local Manufacturing Advantage

Tilda Larsson from AB Ludwig Svensson (Sweden, founded 1887) revealed a crucial insight about DPP implementation:

**THE CHALLENGE FOR MOST COMPANIES:**

"When I discussed with other companies in the project they told me about their supply chains and how many steps they need to go back in the supply chain to get information."

Multi-tier global supply chains:
‚Ä¢ Fiber grown (Country A)
‚Ä¢ Yarn spun (Country B)
‚Ä¢ Fabric woven (Country C)
‚Ä¢ Garment sewn (Country D)
‚Ä¢ Finishing (Country E)
‚Ä¢ Distribution (Country F)

Getting data? Nightmare. üò∞

**THE ADVANTAGE FOR LUDWIG SVENSSON:**

"I can contact all the departments here and I can receive the information very easy and very quick."

Full production in-house:
‚úÖ Yarn dyeing
‚úÖ Warping
‚úÖ Weaving
‚úÖ Knitting
‚úÖ Finishing
‚úÖ Piece dyeing

All under one roof since 1887.

THE BUSINESS CASE:

üéØ DPP becomes **mandatory for EU market access by 2030**

üèÜ Companies with:
‚Ä¢ Local/regional production
‚Ä¢ Integrated supply chains
‚Ä¢ Direct supplier relationships
...will find compliance FAR easier

‚ö†Ô∏è Companies with:
‚Ä¢ Long global supply chains
‚Ä¢ Multi-tier suppliers
‚Ä¢ Opaque processes
...will struggle and spend more

**Compliance becomes competitive advantage.**

As Gisle Mariani Mardal (NFTA, Norway) explained:

**"Not having control is expensive. Once you have control, it's easier to cost cut."**

THE STRATEGIC IMPLICATIONS:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Reshoring becomes more economically viable
2Ô∏è‚É£ Local suppliers gain advantage
3Ô∏è‚É£ Transparency = premium pricing opportunity
4Ô∏è‚É£ Supply chain complexity = hidden DPP cost
5Ô∏è‚É£ Control = resilience + compliance + cost savings

Tilda's vision:

**"It should not be hard to be sustainable, to make sustainable choices. It should be easy for you to do that, easy to do right."**

DPP isn't just regulation.

It's a restructuring force for global supply chains.

And local manufacturing just became a lot more attractive.

Is your organization ready for mandatory DPP?

#DigitalProductPassport #DPP #ESPR #SupplyChain #LocalManufacturing #Reshoring #Sustainability #TextileIndustry #CircularEconomy #Compliance
speaker: Tilda Larsson & Gisle Mariani Mardal
media_suggestion: Infographic contrasting local vs. global supply chain DPP complexity
